questions.text: What does CPU stand for?

optionMap.B: Central Processing Unit
optionMap.C: Computer Processing Utility

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of an operating system?

optionMap.B: Google Chrome
optionMap.C: Windows 11

questions.text: What is the function of RAM in a computer?

optionMap.B: Process video graphics
optionMap.C: Provide short-term memory for active tasks

questions.text: What does "URL" stand for?

optionMap.B: Uniform Resource Locator
optionMap.C: Unified Reference Locator

questions.text: Which device is used to input data into a computer?

optionMap.B: Speaker
optionMap.C: Printer

questions.text: Which of these is a web browser?

optionMap.B: Firefox
optionMap.C: Excel

questions.text: What is the purpose of a firewall?

optionMap.B: To protect against unauthorized access
optionMap.C: To display graphics

questions.text: Which file extension is commonly used for a text file?

optionMap.B: .exe
optionMap.C: .jpg

questions.text: What should you do if your computer freezes?

optionMap.B: Turn off the monitor
optionMap.C: Restart the computer

questions.text: What is the cloud used for in computing?

optionMap.B: Securing physical devices
optionMap.C: Storing and accessing data over the internet

questions.text: If it takes 5 machines 5 minutes to make 5 parts, how long would it take 100 machines to make 100 parts?

optionMap.B: 5 minutes
optionMap.C: 100 minutes

questions.text: What comes next in the pattern? 2, 6, 12, 20, __ ?
You have a 3-liter and a 5-liter container. How can you measure exactly 4 liters?

optionMap.B: Fill the 5-liter and pour into 3-liter until it’s full
optionMap.C: Fill the 3-liter and 5-liter once

questions.text: Which number logically completes the sequence? 1, 4, 9, 16, 25, __ ?
A bat and a ball cost $1.10 in total. The bat costs $1 more than the ball. How much does the ball cost?
If all Bloops are Razzies and all Razzies are Lazzies, are all Bloops definitely Lazzies?

optionMap.B: No
optionMap.C: Only sometimes

questions.text: A farmer has 17 sheep, and all but 9 run away. How many are left?
What is the missing letter in the series? J, F, M, A, M, J, __ , A

optionMap.B: N
optionMap.C: J

questions.text: You’re in a room with 3 light switches and a closed door. One switch controls a light bulb inside the room. How can you find out which one it is by entering the room only once?

optionMap.B: Flip two switches
optionMap.C: Turn one switch on, wait, turn it off, then turn another one on and enter

questions.text: Which of the following is the odd one out?

optionMap.B: Banana
optionMap.C: Carrot

questions.text: Why do you want to join a coding bootcamp?

optionMap.A: I want to try something new, but I’m not sure if coding is for me.
optionMap.B: I want to switch careers, and I think coding might be a good fit for me.
optionMap.C: I am passionate about technology and see this as a stepping stone for a long-term career in software development.

questions.text: What excites you the most about learning to code?

optionMap.A: I just want to see if I like it, no specific reason.
optionMap.B: I like the idea of problem-solving and creating something from scratch.
optionMap.C: I love technology and want to build impactful projects that solve real-world problems.

questions.text: Have you ever tried learning programming on your own? If so, what challenges did you face?

optionMap.A: No, I have never tried coding before.
optionMap.B: Yes, but I struggled with consistency and motivation.
optionMap.C: Yes, I have worked through tutorials, but I need structured guidance to improve.

questions.text: How many hours per week are you willing to dedicate to coding outside of class?

optionMap.B: Between 5 to 10 hours.
optionMap.C: More than 10 hours—I'm fully committed.

questions.text: What do you hope to achieve by the end of the bootcamp?

optionMap.A: Just exploring options, no concrete goals yet.
optionMap.B: I want to learn enough to apply for junior-level jobs.
optionMap.C: I want to build a strong portfolio, land a tech job, and continue learning post-bootcamp.

questions.text: How do you handle failure when learning a new skill?

optionMap.A: I tend to get frustrated and give up easily.
optionMap.B: I struggle but try to push through with some motivation.
optionMap.C: I see failure as a learning opportunity and keep improving.

questions.text: Describe a situation where you had to solve a difficult problem. How did you approach it?

optionMap.A: I usually ask for help immediately.
optionMap.B: I try to figure things out but sometimes get stuck and need help.
optionMap.C: I research solutions, experiment with different approaches, and persist until I solve the problem.

questions.text: How comfortable are you with working under tight deadlines?

optionMap.A: I find deadlines stressful and overwhelming.
optionMap.B: I manage well with some pressure but struggle with very tight deadlines.
optionMap.C: I work well under pressure and stay focused on delivering results.

questions.text: Are you more motivated by personal growth or career advancement?

optionMap.A: I’m not sure, I just want to try coding.
optionMap.B: I want to advance my career, but I also enjoy learning new skills.
optionMap.C: Both—career growth and personal development are equally important to me.

questions.text: Have you ever built something (a project, website, app, etc.)?

optionMap.A: No, I have never tried before.
optionMap.B: Yes, I followed tutorials but didn't build something independently.
optionMap.C: Yes, I built my own projects and want to take them further with structured learning.

questions.text: How do you stay motivated when facing a difficult challenge?

optionMap.A: I often get discouraged and step away.
optionMap.B: I take breaks but eventually push through.
optionMap.C: I enjoy problem-solving and see challenges as growth opportunities.

questions.text: What do you know about the demands and intensity of a coding bootcamp?

optionMap.A: I don’t know much, but I hope it’s not too hard.
optionMap.B: I know it’s intensive, but I’m ready to try.
optionMap.C: I fully understand the intensity and am prepared for the challenge.

questions.text: Are you willing to work on coding exercises daily, even when not in class?

optionMap.A: Not really, I prefer structured lessons only.
optionMap.B: I will try, but I may not always have time.
optionMap.C: Yes, I am committed to daily coding practice.

questions.text: Do you enjoy solving logical problems, like puzzles or brain teasers?

optionMap.A: Not really, I find them frustrating.
optionMap.B: I enjoy them occasionally but don’t seek them out.
optionMap.C: Yes, I love problem-solving and logical thinking.

questions.text: What do you think will be your biggest challenge during the bootcamp?

optionMap.A: Keeping up with the workload and motivation.
optionMap.B: Balancing time and understanding complex topics.
optionMap.C: Making sure I get hands-on experience and apply what I learn.

questions.text: How do you plan to balance your personal life and the bootcamp workload?

optionMap.A: I haven't thought about it yet.
optionMap.B: I will try to manage my time effectively.
optionMap.C: I have a plan in place to balance work, study, and rest.

questions.text: What do you expect from your instructors and peers during the bootcamp?

optionMap.A: I expect full guidance without much self-learning.
optionMap.B: I want support but understand I need to put in effort.
optionMap.C: I expect collaboration, mentorship, and independent learning.

questions.text: How do you react to constructive criticism and feedback?

optionMap.B: I accept feedback but sometimes struggle with it.
optionMap.C: I actively seek feedback and use it to improve.

questions.text: Have you ever worked in a team on a technical or problem-solving project?

optionMap.B: Yes, but I struggle with teamwork sometimes.
optionMap.C: Yes, I thrive in a team environment.

questions.text: On a scale of 1 to 10, how committed are you to completing this bootcamp?

optionMap.A: Below 5 – I am not sure yet.
optionMap.B: 5-7 – I am committed but have concerns.
optionMap.C: 8-10 – I am fully committed to finishing the program.
